comment._content: These children were probably dressed up nicely like this to create a heart-tugging image for northerners, thereby helping the abolitionist cause. comment.author: 21262731@N02
comment._content:
It's not about complexion; it's about ancestry.
Miscegenation was a fact of life in those day.  Some slaves (including former slave Booker T. Washington) had white fathers, the original slave owner.  Two "married" biracial slaves or a biracial slave and her white slave owner could produce children who could  "pass" for white, like these children (if they were indeed slaves).  
If one was born from a community of slaves, they were doomed to continue being slaves, regardless of how light their complexion was.
Quite frankly though, I believe the caption to this photo is rather dubious.

comment.author: 61361160@N00
comment._content: It's also about the registration of skin tone on film -- the children could well have had darker skin to the unfiltered human eye but the combination of light, negative, and print processing could have lightened that appearance, not necessarily intentionally.
